Wages Data from National Longitudinal Survey of Youth

Source: R/wages_hs2020.R
wages_hs2020.Rd

A data set contains longitudinal data of mean hourly wages along with several demographic variables from National Longitudinal Survey of Youth (NLSY) from Round 1 (1979 survey year) to Round 28 (2018 survey year). The cohort provided in this data set are those with maximum highest grade completed is high school and participated at least 5 years in the survey.

wages_hs2020

Format

A data frame with 103,994 rows and 15 variables:

id

A unique individual's ID number. This is the key of the data.

year

The year the observation was taken. This could be the index of the data.

mean_hourly_wage

The mean of the hourly wages the individual gets at each of their different jobs.

age_1979

The age of the subject in 1979.

gender

Gender of the subject, FEMALE and MALE.

race

Race of the subject, NON-BLACK,NON-HISPANIC; HISPANIC; BLACK.

hgc

Highest grade completed.

hgc_i

Integer of highest grade completed.

yr_hgc

The year when the highest grade completed.

number_of_jobs

Number of jobs that an individual has.

total_hours

The number of hours the individual usually works per week.

is_wm

Whether the mean hourly wage is calculated by weighted using the hour work as the weightor regular/arithmetic mean. TRUE = is weighted mean. FALSE = is regular mean.

is_locf

Whether the mean hourly wage is derived from the previous's year value (last observation carried forward) because mean hourly wage in that year is extreme (Q3 + 3xIQR or below Q1 - 3xIQR). TRUE = is locf. FALSE = is not locf.

is_ext_id

Whether the id's average of mean hourly wage is much higher that other ids (extreme). TRUE = The id is extreme. FALSE = The id is not extreme.

is_ext_obs

Whether the mean hourly wage is extreme. TRUE = The id is extreme. FALSE = The id is not extreme.

Source

The NLSY79 Database

Examples

# show the data
wages_hs2020

#> # A tibble: 103,994 x 15
#>       id  year mean_hourly_wage age_1979 gender race  hgc   hgc_i yr_hgc
#>    <int> <int>            <dbl>    <int> <fct>  <fct> <fct> <int>  <int>
#>  1     2  1979             3.85       20 FEMALE NON-… 12TH…    12   1985
#>  2     2  1980             4.57       20 FEMALE NON-… 12TH…    12   1985
#>  3     2  1981             5.14       20 FEMALE NON-… 12TH…    12   1985
#>  4     2  1982             5.71       20 FEMALE NON-… 12TH…    12   1985
#>  5     2  1983             5.71       20 FEMALE NON-… 12TH…    12   1985
#>  6     2  1984             5.14       20 FEMALE NON-… 12TH…    12   1985
#>  7     2  1985             7.71       20 FEMALE NON-… 12TH…    12   1985
#>  8     2  1986             7.69       20 FEMALE NON-… 12TH…    12   1985
#>  9     2  1987             8.79       20 FEMALE NON-… 12TH…    12   1985
#> 10     2  1988             6.67       20 FEMALE NON-… 12TH…    12   1985
#> # … with 103,984 more rows, and 6 more variables: number_of_jobs <int>,
#> #   total_hours <int>, is_wm <lgl>, is_locf <lgl>, is_ext_id <lgl>,
#> #   is_ext_obs <lgl>
# turn the data into a tsibble object
library(brolgar)

#> Warning: package ‘brolgar’ was built under R version 4.0.2
wages <- as_tsibble(x = wages_hs2020,
                    key = id,
                    index = year,
                    regular = FALSE)
# create the spaghetti plot of the data
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(wages) +
    geom_line(aes(x = year,
                  y = mean_hourly_wage,
                  group = id), alpha = 0.1)
